32.29.text:
Coming up. It's Christmas and the Schools
Challenge has given kids the chance to shoot

40.12.text:
We have some of the silliness that goes on
behind the scenes as we make Fieldsports Britain

44.68.text: for you. It's the 2012 blooper reel

46.80.text:
First, I hope you have over indulged, sitting
there on your new DFS sofa and watching this

54.93.text:
on your new iPad Tablet. Well we are going
to self indulge now with our review of 2012.

61.60.text:
If you are watching this on Youtube you can
click on the links on the screen to go straight

67.65.text:
For most UK fieldsports, January is a time
to start winding down - and January 2012 was

72.93.text:
no exception. The wildfowling, hunting and
gamebird seasons are in full swing but their

77.87.text:
ends are in sight. Not for us. 2012 was a
time to wind up, starting with our story about

84.06.text:
Britain's biggest fox, which appeared in The
Sun newspaper on 2nd January.

89.71.text:
It would turn out to be the year of the fox
- but more of that later. Our next stop in

94.91.text:
January was Las Vegas for the biggest sporting
gun show in the world, the Shot Show, where

100.78.text:
you get to see the latest kit available and
I get to fire machine guns in the desert.

108.92.text:
We saw the American obsession with quite an
unusual species.

111.79.text:
They have got Zomby ammunition, Zomby firearms.
Throughout the whole show there are countless

118.14.text:
products from people we are working with who
want to go round with us because because if

122.52.text:
you have the Zomby gun then you need something
to shoot.

126.04.text:
I also got to try out some US hunting. I enjoyed
duck, wild boar and whitetail deer in the

132.01.text:
bayous of Louisiana, and got terrified by
an Armadillo

136.32.text:
My heart started racing and thank goodness
it is an Armadillo. I really thought we were

146.98.text:
We also used our trip to the USA to launch
a new YouTube star. Usually more comfortable

152.16.text:
shooting antelope in Africa, we took Ian Harford
of Team Wild skimming over the swamps in search

160.11.text:
We got home just in time for the end of the
pheasant season. Mark Gilchrist enjoyed a

164.26.text:
day out with the shooters at the Royal Agricultural
College in Cirencester.

169.61.text:
And then there were more foxes. A viewer sent
us this film of an experiment he conducted

174.76.text:
in his garden. Filmed from his front room,
it shows a fox taking not a baby but a dead

180.40.text:
piglet dressed in a baby grow, stuck in a
pram with the sound of a baby crying playing

184.66.text:
on speakersa round it. Ooh - it didn't make
the antis happy at all. More on that later,

191.56.text:
Antis have never liked us. They put themselves
through what must be the misery for them of

196.17.text:
watching our films and then, once they are
properly frothed up, they leave death threats

200.92.text:
in the YouTube comments section. Duh. It's
one of the most public forums in the world.

206.44.text:
It didn't take long to track one of them down,
ring him up and confront him. Does he really

212.86.text:
His behaviour is primitive, backward and he
belongs in the Neolithic era.

218.56.text:
Antis have sad lives. We have fun. The legend
that is Roy Lupton invented a new way of testing

226.30.text: his wild boar shooting skills in March.

234.02.text:
We run the Countryside Alliance film unit
and we did lots of filming for them this year.

238.52.text:
Whether it was the Countryside Alliance awards,
also known as the Rural Oscars, or whippets

243.02.text:
in the snow in the Yorkshire Dales with David
Taylor, or a day out with Nicky Sadler and

247.77.text:
the Ledbury Hunt in Herefordshire, or welcoming
the new chief executive, General Sir Barney

252.75.text:
White-Spunner, who has strong views on repealing
the foxhunting and coursing ban.

259.50.text:
March also saw the European version of the
ShotShow. Held in Nuremberg and called IWA,

264.43.text:
the talk this year was of the German who used
a Sauer bolt action rifle to pull off this

271.55.text:
By April, the fly fishers are getting itchy
fingers. We made a piece about reservoir fishing

278.55.text:
at a water that, because of the lack of rain,
was only half full. The only fisherman catching

285.30.text:
Lack of rain! Ha! Why do you think we are
filming this indoors? Our next stop was truly

292.59.text:
dry. Zeiss Sports Optics held a week-long
hunt to try out its new Conquest HD and Victory

298.23.text:
HT range of scopes and binoculars at the Blaser
Safari Lodge in Namibia. Also on hand were

304.51.text:
experts from Norma ammunition. We learnt about
oryx, red hartebeest, blue wildebeest, more

310.44.text:
oryx, how to use a dead giraffe as bait for
jackals, we were just hanging out at the luxury

316.07.text:
lodge doing luxury stuff when I got a lesson
in how to release a leopard that I didn't

321.71.text:
Back in the UK and we hooked up with some
of the biggest stars of YouTube to try out

326.73.text:
various shooting sports. Our glamorous stars
Roy Lupton, Mark Gilchrist and the incredible

332.64.text: Andy Crow were all on hand to help out.

336.81.text:
But shooting is not always popular, though
we still find that hard to believe. I appeared

340.97.text:
on a TV programme called Foxes Live, where
I had a tough argument with foxlover, rock

345.95.text: guitarist and national treasure Brian May.

349.56.text:
More about Bri (as I call him) later. Another
star we have been doing a lot of work with

354.82.text:
this year is George Digweed. The twenty-times
world champ shoots clays - of that there is

360.38.text:
no doubt - but he also runs pheasant shoots,
designs clay grounds and clay competitions,

365.49.text:
shoots foxes and, to relax, he goes out after
pigeons. We helped The Shooting Show get off

371.03.text:
the ground on YouTube in the summer and George
kindly agreed to let us film him for one of

377.40.text:
Now you might have missed it but Team GB found
a new star in young shooter Peter Wilson,

382.30.text:
who won gold for Double Trap at London2012.
We made a series of films for the Clay Pigeon

388.10.text:
Shooting Association with him and with fourth-in-the-world
women's Olympic Trap shooter Abbey Burton.

393.45.text:
It's amazing that the weather held off for
the Olympics. By the middle of the summer,

397.33.text:
reservoirs were filling up nicely. We were
at lots of events this year, from Irish game

401.30.text:
fairs to all the Schools Challenge events,
including the Universities Challenge, to the

405.77.text: sad cancellation of the CLA Game Fair.

409.38.text:
This is the time of year to experience the
extraordinary sight of roebucks rutting, and

413.46.text:
Roy delivered us to exactly the right place
for that

417.53.text:
It's now August and gameshooting in the UK
starts again with the Glorious Twelfth, the

421.87.text:
official beginning of the grouse season on
the glorious 12th. We try both kinds of this

427.39.text:
fabulous sport - walked up with Lee Maycock,
in order to show off the work of the Moorland

431.85.text:
Association and the Game-to-Eat campaign,
and driven with Simon Ward, one of the country's

437.32.text:
best grouse shots, and Mark Osborne of grand
old gunmaker William Powell.

443.00.text:
....so where you have shot is not where the
grouse are. Really amazing, amazing.

448.44.text:
Grouse shooting can be a rich man's sport.
Pigeon shooting is the poor man's grouse and

452.89.text:
we were able to experiment this year with
some new filming techniques that allow shooters

456.61.text:
to see exactly what shot does and where it
goes. We did this with part-man, part pigeon

465.20.text:
We took similar techniques out with Roy Lupton
on an airgun safari, which allowed us to answer

469.86.text:
the question, can rabbits hear the pellet
before it hits them? This super-ninja bunny

475.41.text: could have had a part in the Matrix.

477.53.text:
I enjoyed one of my favourite summer sports
- prawning in North Cornwall - and Sporting

483.68.text: Shooter editor Dom Holtam went to

485.31.text:
Meanwhile, Roy gets to go shooting in a shopping
centre. Now - he is not running amok with

490.97.text:
an assault rifle, but targeting pesky feral
pigeons with an airgun.

494.08.text:
As summer turns to autumn, the wildfowling,
partridge and then pheasant-shooting seasons

499.64.text:
begin. One of our longest-standing supporters
is Browning, which has a super new shotgun

504.44.text:
this year in the 725, which we launched for
them in the UK, before it was even launched

510.08.text:
in the US. We now go over to Paris with the
guys from Browning for a partridge shoot to

519.53.text:
We are also in Hungary with Euro-hunting star
Max Hunt who talks us through bowhunting,

524.91.text:
putting us right in the idle of the fallow
rut.

532.07.text:
Back in the UK, Dom Holtam gets a good gig
and we go along for the ride. We become one

536.92.text:
of only a few British-based TV shows to try
out the new Ferrari FF shooting break, so

543.48.text:
to celebrate, we set about the Ferrari Macnab
- three days, 700 miles, a stag in Cornwall,

549.29.text:
a grouse in Yorkshire and a salmon in the
north of Scotland.

553.83.text:
The badger cull debate is underway in the
UK. The idea is to shoot 75% of badgers in

558.76.text:
a couple of areas and see if that has an effect
on bovine tuberculosis, which badgers carry.

564.69.text:
Brian May wades in and so incenses country
folk that one of them starts shooting badgers

569.63.text: anyway and sends us the footage.

572.48.text:
We have a lot of fun with Brian this year.
And finally, a deerstalker rings us up and

576.50.text:
tells us that Brian allowed deerstalking in
woodland he owns in Dorset. Such shocking

581.61.text:
double standards - what can we do but telephone
the Sunday Times. Brian is very cross.

587.84.text:
At the end of the year and we stay busy busy
busy. Roy conducts a super airgun pellet test

592.69.text:
to see if the pointy ones, the flat ones or
the domed ones are best for killing rabbits.

596.83.text:
Vinnie Jones sends us pictures of his Russian
Macnabski: a fox, a raccoon dog and a salmon,

601.43.text:
all in one day. Andy Crow is out after crows.
And Mark Gilchrist gets his kit off in our

605.83.text:
super test of different camouflage patterns.
We could not have done this without them,

611.17.text:
so thank you so much to all our stars. Nor
could we have made it without our sponsors.

616.85.text:
Contrary to some people's opinions, David
and I are not eccentric millionaires devoted

621.56.text:
to bringing you weekly entertainment. And
it's thanks to you, the viewer, too. We are

626.90.text:
the biggest hunting channel in Europe and
among the biggest in the world. Thank you

634.13.text:
If you love reviews of years, you might like
to click on the screen and go back and see

638.43.text:
our 2011 review, where I look about five years
younger. I would tell you what we have got

643.37.text: planned for 2013 but I have got no idea.

645.58.text:
Now, let's go to our 2012 for our blooper
reel.

650.83.text: Do you want a bit more animation.

658.01.text: Here you go David, another beer you owe us.

676.47.text: What was that with the net?

682.74.text:
Cut.....cut......cut......shit I shouldn't
have said that......

694.30.text: What ever, I did my best.

694.97.text: Hey Gilchrist you have got fleas mate.

695.74.text:
I am pretty fearful I may vomite before the
end of the day. Can you get off the bucket

704.10.text: I should be at home with a cup of tea.

716.34.text:
Oooh........argh..........ahhh.........I mustn't
argue with a cow.

725.58.text:
I am doing me bungs up so that we can get
back across.

734.71.text: There is one for the Christmas blooper reel.

738.26.text: I know a girl like this.....

757.61.text:
Anybody who says fishing is idyllic needs
their brains tested.

765.50.text: First, it is the next one......no

770.52.text: I am going to be ten, five minutes

774.65.text: Someone said I look like brains on holiday.

780.33.text: I am not an aggressive person am I.

790.17.text: Did I look at you again.

794.63.text:
Thank you Ricky. Welcome to Fieldsports Britain
coming to you this week from Namibia. Coming

799.98.text: That is my line......we have got.....

817.57.text:
For those of you wondering why we are whispering
it is because we are f.......... hunting.

832.42.text: Mind your arm, yes....look at him.

841.37.text:
Where do you get your belly from Dom? I want
one like that, but I just can't afford it.

854.38.text: I have done a lot of angry birds..

862.54.text:
Is awesome......that is horrible. The price
for perfection .........the price for perfection

876.43.text:
on the other hand, the price for perfection.......f......hell,
the price for ferfection......I can't say

888.89.text: Going to see a man about a rod.

891.21.text: I have gone way past the door. When you stopped......

899.38.text:
No I have had no trimming. I have not been
to the salon.

906.51.text:
Can you put more of it up your arse so you
have got more on your front.

917.33.text: Ok I had it on wrong. It is alright.

927.15.text: Yes, that is alright. How alright out of ten?

940.35.text:
Justin doesn't know the chaps that shoot it
so....just there we go.....Justin doesn't

946.93.text:
know the people that shoot it, Justin doesn't
know the people that shoot it, but

953.54.text: Does Justin know the people that shoot it?

967.86.text: Andy go back to the car.

972.57.text: Ok and eventually we got onto this fox .......

991.87.text:
From grown ups making mistakes to kids getting
it right. It is the end of the Schools Challenge

1002.15.text:
series of events this year, the 2012 Game
Day.

1012.40.text:
Fed up with the kids hogging the sofa and
emptying the fridge? Here's a great way to

1017.12.text:
get them out in the fresh air doing something
worthwhile. Send them game shooting.

1026.40.text:
These under-21s have come to the Oxford Gun
Company for the Schools Challenge two-day

1033.63.text:
There are fifteen youngsters in all. Some
of them are already old hands at game shooting.

1039.04.text: But for others, there's a lot to learn.

1041.19.text:
I have shot with air rifles and stuff just
at targets. I have done rabbit hunting a couple

1047.64.text:
of times, but haven't been able to shoot anything
because I haven't had a gun when there have

1056.24.text:
been any rabbits around. That is basically
all I have done. I shot a squirrel once with

1061.07.text:
a shot gun and that is about it. And I am
basically learning to shoot for the first

1067.82.text: time properly with a shot gun on this course.

1070.62.text:
You have been banned from using mobile phones
is that a problem.

1076.42.text:
I was just wondering why you can't use them,
but they made it clear that it is a bit of

1082.60.text:
danger hazard I guess. No that is fine. I
will just turn it off.

1088.63.text:
Tattie is getting the hang of the shooting,
and she's worked out there's more than one

1092.44.text: way to smash a clay pigeon.

1095.37.text:
Let's hope the instructors explain that's
not how we do it with pheasants.

1099.71.text:
The standard of shooting is coming on in leaps
and bounds and, of course our aspiring guns

1105.13.text: can't resist a bit of competition.

1106.91.text:
They are all good really you can't really
.....

1110.11.text:
We have all got our competition mind on in
the back of our heads.

1114.61.text:
At the end of the day we are all doing it
for a bit of a laugh. It is really good fun.

1122.58.text:
Obviously there are only two girls, so it
is sort of girls versus boys, which is quite

1125.27.text: Who is winning at the moment.

1126.26.text: I think it is the girls.

1130.53.text:
As well as marksmanship, the youngsters learn
about safety, etiquette, and how a game shoot

1135.56.text:
works. There's even a demonstration of dog-training
so they can appreciate the important work

1142.84.text:
By the end of day one, everyone has had loads
of fun and smashed plenty of clays, but do

1149.08.text:
they feel confident enough to tackle the real
thing tomorrow?

1151.99.text:
They are all good shots they will have a good
day.

1155.39.text: Because we had Robert teaching us.

1159.42.text:
It's day two, before dawn, and our eager pheasant
shooters are on parade, kitted out in full

1165.21.text:
waterproofs. The forecast isn't good - it's
supposed to rain for most of the day.

1171.13.text:
We gather in front of the big house for a
briefing and photo opportunity. Then we load

1176.44.text:
up and set off - courtesy of sponsors Express
Cartridges and Land Rover.

1184.28.text:
For the first drive the guns are in a ploughed
field, in front of a cover strip. Each of

1189.23.text:
the young shots is accompanied by an instructor
to give them advice and make sure the safety

1195.19.text:
Looking after Laura is David Florent from
The Oxford Gun Company, who's in charge of

1200.41.text:
It is going to be good. It is my first shoot
so hopefully it will go well. There are three

1207.39.text:
of us who haven't shot before so it will be
really good. The experience to do all three

1216.84.text:
Laura is excited about the possibility of
shooting her first ever pheasant - but nervous

1221.92.text: about actually handling a dead one.

1224.43.text: She is going to carry it in a minute.

1229.42.text:
Yes you are. You shot it so you are carrying
it.

1230.34.text:
Can I just go and get my gloves. I have to
wear my gloves.

1234.77.text:
With the 15 youngsters split into three teams,
they take it in turns to shoot, beat and pick-up.

1241.07.text:
Eventually it's Tattie's turn to shoot - and
she really wants to get her first pheasant

1247.11.text: Those two weren't easy were they?

1254.01.text:
By now everyone's worked up an appetite, and
the youngsters pounce on the soup and hot

1258.73.text:
sausages. As for the fudge fingers, we still
don't know where the box ended up.

1264.66.text:
Anyway, back to work, and the rain has arrived,
which is going to put those waterproofs to

1269.07.text:
the test. Still, we're too busy trying to
keep in line to notice.

1273.67.text:
A couple of drives later, Tattie gets her
second chance - will she manage to bag her

1282.49.text: My hands are freezing. Ha I got two.

1296.75.text:
Yes......go on, in front, in front. He's got
it. Break the gun, break the gun. Shut the

1316.73.text:
Well she's achieved her ambition, and learnt
something about the neighbouring gun poaching

1322.64.text:
Meanwhile, Laura's shooting is going from
strength to strength - she's had another pheasant

1326.79.text:
and even shared a woodcock with her brother.
But she's still struggling with actually picking

1331.57.text:
up a dead bird. Still, at least everyone is
being sensitive and understanding about it.

1340.93.text: You can't shoot them if you can't hold them.

1351.35.text: I can't put it on my arm.

1356.55.text:
Don't be a wimp, just hold it. It is just
feathers.

1364.20.text: Can you hold it with me?

1370.99.text: Right, time for lunch, form an orderly queue...

1374.98.text:
With storm clouds gathering, darkness is coming
early, so there's no time to lose - we've

1379.60.text:
one last drive to fit in. The keeper is showing
huge confidence in our young guns by driving

1385.52.text:
the birds right over the roof of his house.
Let's hope they were paying attention in the

1391.24.text:
No need to worry, these youngster are shooting
like pro's. By the time the drive is over,

1396.46.text:
the bag for the day is 51 plus the woodcock
- and it looks like Laura has conquered her

1402.74.text:
We're finished just in time to hop into the
vehicles before the rain really starts. Then

1407.99.text:
it's back to The Oxford Gun Company for a
debrief before the parents arrive and the

1412.00.text:
youngsters head home bubbling with memories.
So has their experience converted them into

1423.88.text:
Well we are running a year's worth of programming
for Schools Challenge in 2013 on their own

1429.57.text:
dedicated Youtube page. Keep watching for
more details.

1433.85.text:
Now to the wider world of hunting and this
time the third world, it is a tribal version

1442.84.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1446.48.text:
that YouTube has to offer, at this festive
time, from all over the third world.

1451.78.text:
In western Mongolia, an ancient tradition
of hunting with golden eagles is still alive,

1456.26.text:
and it makes for popular films on YouTube.
In this film, the Mongols are launching eagles

1461.97.text:
Heading to North America, I spent a happy
summer in northern Labrador, based out of

1466.12.text:
the mainly Inuit town of Nain. The Inuits
are avid hunters. Here is a film showing a

1470.91.text:
whale hunt with Native Iñupiaq hunters on
the other side of the continent in northern

1475.24.text:
Alaska. Like the Mongols and their eagles,
the Iñupiaq people have been hunting whales

1481.12.text:
Earlier this year, I learnt to hunt dangerous
African animals by throwing sticks at them.

1485.54.text:
Next up, we're hunting with the Hadzabe tribe
of Tanzania. Don't expect lions. They kill

1490.34.text:
three birds and a squirrel, cook and eat them
and then show how to use their bows and arrows.

1495.46.text:
On the fishing front, as a serial prawner,
I am struck by this simple shrimp fishing

1499.95.text:
film from Thailand. Google translation into
English from Thai is "Naturally fall under

1506.35.text:
Let's go spearfishing in the Amazon. This
guy is incredible. We're in the Pacaya Samiria

1511.02.text:
National Reserve in Northern Peru. A local
guide and fisherman spots a fish and kebabs

1516.98.text:
Staying in South America, a couple of National
Geographic filmmakers made this short film

1521.08.text:
for their YouTube channel with the Kaapor
people of Brazil. It's subsistence stuff - they

1527.59.text:
Think Australia and you think roos. Here the
aboriginal people in the Pilbara, Western

1531.91.text:
Australia, are after kangaroos to feed kids
at a local school. You can pick up kangaroo

1536.62.text: cooking tips from this film, too

1538.50.text:
Finally, just to show that with most third-world
hunting, a big calibre is better than a blowpipe

1543.10.text:
or boomerang, here is Giant Crocodile Hunting,
River Nile, Africa by Ezz El-Rifaie

1548.97.text:
Well I hope that wasn't too tokenistic a romp.
You can click on any of these films to watch

1553.38.text:
them. If you have a Youtube film about any
kind of hunting or fishing you would like

1556.87.text:
us to pop into the weekly top eight then send
it in via Youtube or email me the link at

1563.83.text:
Well we are back next week on the second of
January with a whole host of new programming

1568.61.text:
for 2013 as I say I have no idea what it is
yet. If you are watching this on Youtube,

1573.85.text:
please hit the subscribe button that is somewhere
round the screen or go to our web page www.fieldsportschannel.tv

1579.10.text:
click to like us on Facebook follow us on
Twitter, or scroll down to the bottom, on

1583.52.text:
the right you will see our constant contact
box where you can pop your email address and

1588.44.text:
we will contact you every week with news of
our programme that is out Wednesday evening

1592.21.text:
from seven o'clock. This has been Fieldsports
Britain for 2012. It is a very happy new year.
